metadata.case_name: Madras Dealers (Yarn Merchants) v. State of Andhra Pradesh
metadata.case_number: Original Jurisdiction Petitions Nos. 220, 222, 240 and 380 to 395 of 1955

facts.text: Petitioners are dealers carrying on business in the City of Madras in the sale and purchase of yarn.

Dealers in Andhra would place orders for the purchase of yarn with the petitioners in Madras, contracts concluded at Madras, goods delivered ex-godown at Madras and thereafter despatched to purchasers either by lorries or by rail as directed by them.

When goods sent by rail, railway receipts taken either in name of consignees and sent to them by post or in name of consignor and endorsed to purchasers and delivered in Madras or sent by post endorsed in favour of a bank and purchasers take delivery after payment to bank.
In all cases price of the goods was paid in Madras.

Dispute confined to proposed imposition of tax in so far as it relates to sales of the character mentioned in the Explanation to Art. 286(1)(a), i.e., sales in which property in goods passed outside Andhra but goods actually delivered as result of sale for consumption within that State (Explanation sales).
Andhra State formed part of composite State of Madras; on September 14, 1953, Parliament enacted Andhra State Act 30 of 1953, constituting separate State of Andhra effective October 1, 1953.

Under s.53 Andhra State Act, laws in force in territories prior including Madras General Sales Tax Act (Madras 9 of 1939) continue; Adaptation Order on November 12, 1953 substituted 'Andhra' for 'Madras'.

Board of Revenue (Commercial Taxes) Andhra State issued notification July 13, 1954 calling upon dealers to submit returns of turnover of sales where goods delivered in Andhra for consumption; copy to Madras Yarn Merchants Association.

Association disputed liability; after correspondence, Andhra issued notices June 30, 1955 to petitioners to send returns by July 15, 1955 failing which assessments on best judgment basis and penalties.
Bengal Immunity judgment September 6, 1955 held Explanation sales inter-State, not taxable under Art.286(2) without Parliament lifting ban.
Andhra statement October 21, 1955 admitting petitions might be allowed without costs post-Bengal Immunity.
Sales Tax Validation Ordinance III of 1956 promulgated January 30, 1956; replaced by Sales Tax Laws Validation Act 7 of 1956 effective March 21, 1956.
Andhra Pradesh (post States Reorganisation Act) fresh statement February 19, 1957 claiming entitlement under Validation Act for period April 1, 1951 to September 6, 1955.
Interveners: States of Madras, Bihar, UP; Union of India; assessees Mysore Spinning, Minerva Mills, Tata Iron Steel, Madura Mills.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Andhra-Madhya Act, in fact, imposes a tax on the class of sales falling within the Explanation to Art. 286(1)(a) (Explanation sales)
Whether the Sales Tax Laws Validation Act 1956 (impugned Act) is ultra vires on the ground that it is not authorised by the terms of Art. 286(2)
Whether s.22 of the Andhra-Madhya Act is within the protection of the impugned Act

Whether the impugned Act validates only levies and collections made during the specified period (April 1, 1951 to Sept 6, 1955), or whether it authorises the imposition and collection of taxes on such sales in future

Whether s.22 of the Madras Act was null and void on the ground that it was in contravention of Art. 286(2), and whether the proceedings sought to be taken thereunder on the strength of the impugned Act are incompetent
Whether tax on inter-State sales is within the exclusive competence of Parliament, and whether the impugned Act is, in consequence, bad as authorising the States to levy tax

Whether the proposed imposition of tax is illegal on the ground that successive sales of yarn are subject under the law to be taxed at only one point, and as the State of Madras has already taxed the present sales, the State of Andhra cannot again levy a tax on them
Whether the proposed imposition of tax on yarn by the Andhra State is hit by the Essential Commodities Act read with Art. 286(3), and is illegal

petitioner_arguments.text: Andhra-Madhya Act does not seek to tax Explanation sales at all. It talks of property passing only and as such Andhra can tax only such sales where property passes in Andhra.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Poppatlal Shah v. State of Madras (1953 SCR 677); s.22 does not enlarge definition of sales

petitioner_arguments.text: Explanation to s.22, like Explanation to Art.286(1), merely defines outside sale and not for determining inside sale.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Bengal Immunity Co. case (1955 2 SCR 603 at 640)

petitioner_arguments.text: Power of President under Art.372(2) merely to bring State laws into conformity with Art.286; s.22 introduced by Adaptation Order cannot permit tax on Explanation sales prohibited by Art.286.

Sales Tax Laws Validation Act 1956 not valid under Art.286(2); Parliament can only lift ban on inter-State sales, not validate or ratify State laws; power under Art.286(2) only once, finally, not retrospectively.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art.286(2); Punjab Province v. Daulat Singh (73 IA); Behram Khurshed Pesikaka v. State of Bombay (1955 1 SCR 613); Dialdas v. Talwalkar AIR 1957 Bom 71

petitioner_arguments.text: Validation Act validates only where tax levied/collected; does not confer power to assess/levy where neither done.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Mettur Industries v. State of Madras AIR 1957 Mad 362 (contra but cited)

petitioner_arguments.text: Tax single point; petitioners paid tax at purchase from mills, no second tax.
Petitioners not dealers in AP; no sales in AP, all in Madras; tax hit by Essential Commodities Act r/w Art.286(3).
S.22 does not authorise tax on Explanation sales; non-obstante subtracts, does not add.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Ram Narain Sons v. Asst. Commr. (1955 2 SCR 483); Aswini Kumar Ghosh v. Arbinda Bose (1953 SCR 1)

respondent_arguments.text: Petitions premature; facts of each sale yet to be investigated.
State taxing under United Motors decision.
Explanation to s.22 read with definition of sale adds Explanation sales as taxable inside sales.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Art.372(2); Art.286(1) implicit delivery State taxes

respondent_arguments.text: Validation Act valid under Art.286(2); lifts ban retrospectively; legislative power includes retrospective.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Art.286(2); Bhikaji Narain v. State of MP (1955 2 SCR 589)

respondent_arguments.text: S.22 conditional legislation; becomes operative when Parliament lifts ban.
Entry 42 List I no taxation power; taxes in Entries 82-92.
Validation Act not temporary; operates now for specified period sales; States can initiate proceedings now.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Sales Tax Laws Validation Act s.2

court_reasoning.text: Sales not all same kind; dispute confined to Explanation sales.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Validity requires fact determination but confined to Explanation sales.

court_reasoning.text: Under Madras Act pre-Constitution, tax only if property passes inside State (Poppatlal Shah); Explanation 2 (1948) deems sale inside if goods in province at contract or future goods produced there.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Adaptation Order inserted s.22 reproducing Art.286(1)(a) Explanation.

court_reasoning.text: In taxing statute context, Explanation to s.22 positive: authorises tax on Explanation sales as inside sales; differs from Art.286 context which restricts State power.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Non-obstante controls s.2(h); s.22 and s.2(h) read together deem property passed inside delivery State.

court_reasoning.text: President's power under Art.372(2) includes adapting to confer/enlarge within State competence; non-justiciable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: S.22 imposes tax conditionally on Parliament lifting Art.286(2) ban.

court_reasoning.text: Impugned Validation Act lifts ban under Art.286(2); not mere validation but removes fetter retrospectively; Parliament power legislative includes retrospective.
court_reasoning.key_observation: To redress evils post-Bengal Immunity: save collections, pending assessments.

court_reasoning.text: S.22 within impugned Act protection; authorises future imposition/collection for specified period sales.
Text cut off but implies rejection of other issues like single point tax, essential commodities.

holdings.text: Andhra-Madhra Act (s.22) imposes tax on Explanation sales conditionally on Parliament lifting Art.286(2) ban.
Sales Tax Laws Validation Act 1956 valid under Art.286(2); lifts ban retrospectively for specified period.
S.22 protected by Validation Act; authorises initiation of proceedings post-Act for specified period sales.
S.22 not void; proceedings competent post-Validation Act.

outcome.summary: Court holds Andhra-Madhra Act s.22 imposes conditional tax on Explanation sales; Validation Act validly lifts Art.286(2) ban retrospectively, authorising imposition/collection; petitions challenging tax proceedings dismissed.

key_quotes.text: "the Explanation to s. 22 must mean that it authorises the State of Madras to impose a tax on sales falling within its purview."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Holds s.22 positively authorises tax on Explanation sales in taxing statute context

key_quotes.text: "The true scope of the impugned Act is... that it lifts the ban imposed on the States against taxing inter-State sales and not that it validates or ratifies any such law."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies Validation Act as lifting ban under Art.286(2), not mere validation

key_quotes.text: "s. 22 operated to impose a tax falling within the Explanation, subject to authorisation by Parliament as provided in Art. 286(2)."
key_quotes.speaker: court
